instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Another short on CPU Vcore. This one does heat up the CPU though when I run power through <CAPACITOR>C1031</CAPACITOR> with <RESISTOR>R7310</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7320</RESISTOR> disconnected. Does the fact that I'm seeing heat mean anything positive?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: What do you call a short? What is resistance to GND on Vcore?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: 0.3Ω and 0.000 in diode mode. I use a Fluke meter where measuring from one ground point to another will give me a 0.2Ω reading.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah that is a shorted CPU, the end.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Short on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
